ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

RECENT DEATHS OF NSMEN

     1.  Assoc. Prof. Paulin Tay Straughan asked the Deputy Prime Minister and

Column: 2506

Minister for Defence in light of the tragic deaths of two full-time National Servicemen involving reversing army vehicles, what additional measures have been put in place to prevent such accidents from happening again.

     The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence (Mr Teo Chee Hean): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am saddened by the loss of Lance Corporal (LCP) Eugin Wee Yong Choon on 28th January 2011. I would like to express my deepest condolences to the family.

 

     Assoc. Prof. Straughan referred to two incidents. The first incident occurred on 3rd July 2009 at Seletar Camp. A Motor Transport Officer was pinned under a landrover and succumbed to his injuries in the hospital. A Committee of Inquiry convened to investigate the incident found that the driver of the vehicle had been negligent in his duties as a driver, and had failed to follow the correct vehicle mounting and starting procedures. The Police also conducted a separate and independent investigation. The driver of the vehicle was subsequently charged in Court for causing death by doing a negligent act not amounting to culpable homicide. He pleaded guilty and was fined $5,000 and disqualified from driving all vehicles for four years.

 

     Following this incident one and a half years ago in 2009, MINDEF and the SAF conducted a review on the procedures for vehicle mounting and starting and concluded that they were fundamentally sound, and the incident could have been prevented if the driver had followed them. The SAF has continued to reinforce these procedures and remind its vehicle commanders and drivers to adhere strictly to them before mounting and starting any vehicle.

 

     The most recent incident involving LCP Eugin Wee occurred on 28th January 2011. The SAF immediately ordered a

Column: 2507

safety time-out that same day, for unit commanders to go through with all vehicle commanders and drivers vehicular safety drills and procedures. The SAF does this when there is an incident of note because these are teachable moments when safety procedures are reinforced and lessons learnt are shared, so that every person is aware of the relevance of procedures and safety consciousness. And each person knows that safety is in his hands and that what he does or does not do can have serious consequences on his buddies or himself.

 

     Mr Speaker, MINDEF takes the safety and well-being of our servicemen very seriously. The Army safety system is not simply one which is drawn up on its own but it is also certified in accordance with the Occupational Health and Safety Assessment Series (OHSAS). Adherence to OHSAS provides a comprehensive system of safety management based on a set of standard procedures designed to systematically and methodically manage risks in our work processes. For those who are not familiar with it, OHSAS is an internationally recognised system created by a group of world-leading bodies and consultancies who are the authorities of standards. These include countries like Ireland, Australia, South Africa and Britain.

 

     The Army constantly upkeeps our OHSAS standards and undergoes annual inspection and audit by an independent external agency. In addition, the Army also conducts internal safety management system audits on core Army units. The prescribed safety procedures are hence fundamentally sound but we have to continue to do better to make sure that they are followed.  This includes regular reminders to those responsible for operating vehicles and special reminders during such teachable moments.  However, safety procedures cannot cover every specific condition that may arise. Hence, it is also important that every

Column: 2508

Serviceman has safety consciousness, looks out for the safety of his men, his buddies and himself.

 

     MINDEF is conducting a Commission of Inquiry and the Police is independently conducting its investigations into the death of LCP Wee. As these inquiries are in progress, it would not be appropriate for me to comment further on this specific case incident at this point in time.

     Assoc. Prof. Paulin Tay Straughan (Nominated Member): I would like to thank the Minister for assuring all parents and NSmen that their safety is of primary concern. As my son is a proud member of the SAF now, I am deeply appreciative of the Minister's detailed assurance. I have just one supplementary question. The difficulty for us in all organisations is to guard against human error more than anything else. I would like to ask the Minister if the SAF would consider having a third person involved whenever vehicles are moving forward or backward, to be that extra pair of eyes to check and to ensure that the driver is aware there is a person or persons behind the truck, rather than to just have the driver and whoever is in-charge of off-loading or taking care of those behind-the-vehicle kind of operations.

     Mr Teo Chee Hean: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not sure whether Assoc. Prof. Straughan is referring to a second person or a third person because we already have a second person.

     Assoc. Prof. Paulin Tay Straughan:  The driver who is managing the vehicle, the officer or the man who is behind the vehicle and taking care of his responsibilities back there, and the third person who stands there and says, "Watch out, watch out."

     Mr Teo Chee Hean: Indeed, Sir, for the operation of SAF vehicles, we do have a

Column: 2509

person called the vehicle commander and he is, in fact, responsible. He is the most senior person sitting in the vehicle. He sits next to the vehicle operator, or the driver. It is his responsibility to guide the vehicle operator and to correct him if he sees any situation which requires correction. The vehicle commander may not know the operation of the vehicle itself but he is able to assess the surrounding situation, particularly for safety. In the case where vehicles are manoeuvring in tight or confined spaces, the vehicle commander actually does dismount and guide the driver with hand signals and other signals, and helps to ensure that the area around the vehicle is cleared.  As I have said, every person who is operating vehicles, the vehicle commander and others who are around vehicles have to look after themselves.  We cannot cover every specific situation which may arise when operating a vehicle.

 

     The procedures are also very, very detailed. If I may read the procedures for mounting a vehicle, or the drill which a person is supposed to go through: "open the door wide enough to get in; mount the vehicle with mounting handle; check safety; close the door firmly; check that the master switch, gear and hand brake are in the safe position; locate the main control and devices; adjust seat to correct driving posture; adjust mirrors; put on safety belt."  So, there is a whole sequence of things that a person needs to do. And also before mounting the vehicle: "approach the vehicle from the front; check traffic; move around the vehicle for safety check; remove wheel chocks, obstacles", and so on. There are very detailed procedures. We need to emphasise to our vehicle operators and vehicle commanders that they do have a responsibility to themselves and to their buddies to follow the procedures.

LATEST MEASURES TO COOL PROPERTY MARKET

     2.  Er Lee Bee Wah asked the Minister for National Development (a) what is the compelling factor that prompted the Government to implement the latest property cooling measures; (b) whether the Government analysed buyer data to ascertain whether foreigners or Singaporeans were responsible for the speculative buying; and (c) why the release of state land for housing developments have not had the intended effect.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Mah Bow Tan): Mr Speaker, Sir, the property market was very buoyant last year. To meet the strong demand, the Government had increased the supply of land for private residential development. In 2010, the Government sold land that can potentially yield about 13,300 units. For the first half of 2011, the Government launched sites under the Government Land Sales programme that can yield another 14,300 units. As at the beginning of this year, there were about 33,000 unsold units, or roughly equivalent to three years’ take-up of private residential units, if we go by the average annual take-up rate over the past four years.

 

     Despite the large supply in the pipeline, market sentiments had remained bullish, with signs of renewed exuberance in the market towards the end of last year. The majority of the buyers were Singaporeans. We were particularly concerned that low interest rates plus excessive liquidity in the financial system, both in Singapore and globally, could further drive up demand for private housing. This, in turn, could cause prices to overshoot economic fundamentals. The interest rates would also not continue to stay low. Purchasers who over-extended themselves financially could be caught

Column: 2511

when interest rates eventually rise, and they could be forced to sell their properties at an inopportune time.

 

     Therefore, the Government introduced additional measures in January to pre-empt a property bubble from forming. These measures aimed to temper demand, encourage greater financial prudence among property purchasers and discourage short-term speculation.

 

     We will continue to monitor the property market closely and take further steps, if necessary, to promote a stable and sustainable property market.

     Er Lee Bee Wah (Ang Mo Kio):  Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to ask the Minister what is the intended end-result of the latest cooling measures.  Would the Minister like to see property prices stabilise or go down?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: It is not the intention of the latest measures to crash the market, certainly, but rather to cool the market. Given the current situation of strong economic growth, low interest rates and a lot of liquidity in the market, it is not unnatural to expect that property prices would remain strong. But we do not wish to see prices shooting up so fast as to be unsupportable by the fundamentals in the market. At the same time, we also do not want to see a lot of short-term speculation in the market. Our measures in January were pre-emptive in nature because we wanted to act before a bubble forms. They were calibrated so as to cool the market and not to crash the market. They were very targeted at the short-term speculators and not at genuine home-buyers. If we meet these objectives, then I think the measures would have done the job. It is a little too early to say at this point in time what the outcome of these measures are, what the results are, because it has only been slightly over a month since we introduced the last set of measures. We will continue to monitor the

Column: 2512

market closely and as I have said, if necessary, we will take further measures.

Column: 2512

FEE INCREASES AT POLYTECHNICS

     3.  Mrs Josephine Teo asked the Minister for Education what are the reasons for the consecutive fee increases in 2010 and 2011 for local students studying in polytechnics.

     The Senior Minister of State for Education (Mr S Iswaran) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, polytechnic fees were unchanged for three consecutive years from 2007 to 2009, due to the GST increase in 2007, and the economic downturn in 2008 and 2009.  Subsequently, fees were increased by $50 in each of the Academic Years, 2010 and 2011.

 

 


     The increases were necessary to meet rising costs and, more importantly, because polytechnics continue to invest in capability-building initiatives in order to deliver high-quality education to Singaporeans. Where justified, it is preferable to have regular but small fee increases rather than a significant hike in any one year. Even after the current increase, the Government continues to heavily subsidise the cost of polytechnic education. The Government subsidy amounts to about 86%.  MOE and the polytechnics will also ensure that various modes of financial assistance are available to students and that no eligible or deserving student is denied a polytechnic education due to financial difficulties.

     Mrs Josephine Teo (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have three supplementary questions.  Firstly, given the concerns over rising inflation, could the increases have been further delayed, perhaps for a year? Secondly, could the fee increases have been applied to new cohorts only, in other words, for students who are enrolled from this year onwards? And, thirdly, will financial assistance be expanded in connection with this round of fee increases?

Column: 2513

     Mr Iswaran: Mr Speaker, Sir, I thank the Member for her questions. Could the fee increases have been delayed? Of course, in principle, yes. But I think it is a balance between what is happening on the ground, in terms of the needs of the polytechnics operationally and the costs that they are dealing with, and the plans they have to enhance their capabilities versus upping the burden on students. In this case, if Members look at the order of the magnitude of the increase, it is about 2%. It has gone up from about $2,100 to $2,150, so it is a $50 increase, or about 2%. In the case of most students, it should be within their means to meet that increase.

 

     Secondly, would it be preferable to apply the increase only to new cohorts versus the entire enrolment? The answer is what the past practice has been and maintaining the equity and the treatment. The treatment is always being that the entire enrolment is affected by the fee increase. If we now change the policy, there will be questions of inequitable treatment.

 

     Thirdly, the Member asked for assurances on whether we are expanding the financial assistance scheme. As Members are well aware, we have a whole slew of financial assistance measures, ranging from loans to bursaries and other community-based support measures. At this stage, about half the students in the polytechnics avail themselves of this range of facilities. We will continue to be ready to make them available as required. There is no resource constraint on that score.

     Mrs Josephine Teo: Thank you, Senior Minister of State. I recall that when I was in university and there was a round of fee increases, it applied only to new cohorts. I am making this appeal to the MOE to consider such a practice for the polytechnics. I do not know whether the universities still do that, but I am making

Column: 2514

a case for such a practice, if it has not been in practice, then to be in place. It gives assurances to parents whose children are already enrolled. Sir, I would like MOE to consider that.

     Mr Iswaran: Mr Speaker, Sir, I fully understand where the Member is coming from and I empathise with her motivations. I just want to draw a distinction between the university fees and polytechnic fees. A key consideration is the order of the magnitude of difference. The typical university fees are at least three times what the polytechnic students pay. When we are talking in terms of financial planning, there is a significant difference. In university fees, we look for about 25% cost recovery and we are not quite there yet. In the case of our polytechnic students, it is a far lower target level. We are talking about very different orders of magnitude. But the point is well-taken. In the first instance, our objective is to ensure, and it is a central tenet of our education system, that any deserving student that is admitted to the polytechnics will not be deprived of that education because of financial issues. If it is because of the marginal fee increase, then that will be rectified.

Column: 2514

ETHNIC CLASSIFICATION FOR PSLE RESULTS

     4.  Mr Viswa Sadasivan asked the Minister for Education why is there a need to announce PSLE results along ethnic categories.

     The Minister of State, Ministry of Education (Mr Masagos Zulkifli B M M) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, after each national examination, various ethnic groups and their corresponding language media show keen interest on the identity of the top students from each of their respective communities in order to recognise and celebrate their achievements. The Ministry has therefore been

Column: 2515

releasing listings of the top students from the major races in national examinations since the 1990s.
 

     This practice is consistent with our overall approach of regular release of national examination results by ethnic group since 1988. This provides feedback to the various communities on how their students have fared and to monitor the effectiveness of their programmes.

     Mr Viswa Sadasivan (Nominated Member): Sir, I see the value of ethnic category-based results to ethnic self-help groups, for example. Could the Ministry consider at the mass media level when the information is released to the general public – in other words, the announcement to the public – that it is presented as a whole instead of being divided along ethnic lines? I am concerned about students, in particular ethnic communities, who may not have fared as well. Can I have a response from the Government, please?

     Mr Masagos Zulkifli B M M: Mr Speaker, there is no sinister reason why we communicate this along ethnic lines. Basically, like myself, when the Malay community performs well and the top students are announced, I celebrate just like my community does, and even my wife, when she opens the newspaper in the morning. I think this practice is consistent. We will continue with it. We are celebrating for the four races – Chinese, Malay, Indian and Eurasian – 98% of the community in Singapore.  

Column: 2515

CONSTRUCTION OF NORTH-SOUTH EXPRESSWAY

     5.  Er Lee Bee Wah asked the Minister for Transport with the building of the North-South Expressway (NSE) in highly urbanised areas (a) what are the considerations taken to minimise the impact of noise levels on residents when the NSE is in operation; (b) why certain

Column: 2516

segments of the NSE are not designed as a full tunnel; and (c) what is the total cost of the project and duration of the construction.

     The Minister for Transport (Mr Raymond Lim Siang Keat): Mr Speaker, the North-South Expressway (NSE) is a major road project that will provide a high speed road link to the city centre from residential estates such as Woodlands, Sembawang, Yishun, Ang Mo Kio and Toa Payoh. Many residents will directly benefit from the NSE as travel time to the city is expected to be reduced by up to 30% after its opening. Without the NSE, congestion on major roads along the North-South corridor, such as the CTE and Thomson Road, will build up with the expected future growth in households living in the North. We estimate that the entire NSE project will cost between $7 billion and $8 billion, and that construction will take about six to seven years.

 

     The Government proceeded with the NSE project only after careful planning and deliberation. We considered various factors, including the need to minimise land acquisition and land take, and to mitigate the potential disamenities that could result from the project. We also strived to adopt the most cost-effective solutions available.

 

     As far as possible, LTA has designed the NSE as a full tunnel in the highly urbanised areas. However, this is not always feasible. The NSE was designed as a semi-tunnel between the SLE and south of Ang Mo Kio Avenue 9, and between Sin Ming Avenue and north of Pemimpin Place after careful consideration. In order for these stretches to be full tunnels, more land would be needed for ventilation buildings. These are large buildings, each requiring around 15,000 square metres of land. They have to be sited close to the tunnel, and at certain intervals to fulfil ventilation requirements.   

 

Column: 2517

     The possible sites for these ventilation buildings such as the undeveloped land around Lentor Avenue and Yio Chu Kang Road are encumbered by the existing MRT viaduct or currently form part of MINDEF’s training ground, or are close to Yio Chu Kang MRT Station where the land has been set aside for high-density residential use. To place a ventilation building on any of these sites would put at risk the operations of a live MRT line or impede training for our national defence, or constrain our ability to have more homes in close proximity to the Yio Chu Kang MRT Station. In addition, a ventilation building in the vicinity of Bishan Park would also be required. However, this would adversely affect PUB’s Active, Beautiful and Clean (ABC) upgrading programme at the heavily-used park. 

 

     I hope Members will understand that some difficult decisions had to be taken in order to bring about a major road project like the NSE. The Government had to decide on an alignment and expressway design that takes into consideration the competing land uses while still meeting its intended purpose. 

 

     We recognise that some premise owners and residents may have concerns with noise from the NSE. Let me assure Members that, regardless of the configuration, LTA will ensure that the NSE will comply with NEA’s standards for road traffic noise when the NSE is in operation. LTA will conduct a detailed engineering study and implement appropriate mitigation measures wherever necessary. Possible measures include dense planting, the use of porous asphalt on the road surface, and design features such as shaped screens at the openings of the semi-tunnels to reflect traffic noise away from residents as much as possible.

     Er Lee Bee Wah: Sir, I would like to thank the Minister for the comprehensive

Column: 2518

answer. I have four supplementary questions. Since the announcement of the NSE, I have been receiving overwhelming feedback from my residents from three condominium developments. Due to the overwhelming feedback from the affected residents, I would like to ask the Minister whether he would consider converting the semi-tunnels that are close to the residential area to full tunnels. The second question: how sure is the Minister that the noise mitigation measures just mentioned, for example, the planting, porous asphalt and shaped screens, will work? The third question: how long will LTA take to conclude the details of these noise-mitigation measures studies? Lastly, the six to seven years of construction period is very long for the affected residents. Can the Minister look into phased completion, that is, to get the contractor to finish the stretch near to the residents in a shorter duration?

     Mr Raymond Lim Siang Keat: First, I would like to thank the Member. I know the Member has been working hard and bringing the concerns of the residents to the LTA. LTA has found this very useful, and I think the Member's decision to form a working committee in her constituency to look into this matter is a good one. The Member has my assurance that LTA will work very closely with her on how best to address these concerns.

 

     Let me now take the Member's four supplementary questions. On the issue of whether we could convert the semi-tunnel to a closed tunnel, I have explained in my reply why we could not do so. LTA, in the planning process, considered as one possibility a full tunnel in the affected areas. To do that, they needed to find land to put the ventilation building. The ventilation building is quite sizeable – 15,000 square metres, which is close to two-and-a-half football fields. They have to find land for that. Though it is more commonly used in marketing for customer relationship management, data mining is also widely used by businesses, organisations and individuals as a part of research, trend analysis and other legitimate profiling purposes.  

 

     Given the pervasive usage of data mining as a business tool, data mining activities are not classified as a standalone category in the Singapore Standard Industrial Classification (SSIC). There are therefore no reliable statistics on the number of businesses engaged in such activities.

     The House was previously informed that a study was underway to review the need for a data protection regime in Singapore and to develop a model that can best address consumers’ concerns, business requirements and national interests.
